pageContext.desc: Principal, civil engineer, lumber mill owner, and farmer in New England and the Midwest.

pages.transcription:
Hudson July 29th 1870
My dear husband,
I received your letter
mailed at Easton Pa.. this morning, & the one mailed at Boston.
day before yesterday.Your Insurance ticket came also with the
letter this morning. I am
glad you have got so far, safe.
(I suppose though now you
are at Logansport). You will
expect to get a letter from me
when you get to goodland. but
I hardly think this will reach
there by the time you do. I
have not had any time to
write. it takes some one all
the time to look after Artie.
He is asleep now (noon) & I want
to finish this letter before he wakes.

He seems a little better to-day.
His Diarrhea has been worse
since you went away.  I went 
to the Village yesterday, & got 2oz of
Brandy, 1 oz of peppermint, a pint
of Whiskey, & a bottle of Jamaica
Ginger, + some Rhubarb - the druggist
had no Fusgate's Cordial, but he 
said he would send to Boston 
for some, + I shall get it to day 
I guess.  Georgie says she is better 
to-day - I told him I should

not let him have any thing

to eat but milk toast till he 
was entirely well, + I dont let
Artie have anything else - How
were those medicines to be  mixed
that is, How much Brandy + peppermint
must be put with, 1/2 oz] rhubarb +
the same amount of soda, + is there
any sugar or water to be put with
it + Wnnie + Eddie are well, I am
about the same as when you left.

Am not much better than a
"wooden woman."  I took a
pill last night  + guess I shall 
take another to-night.  I invested
.50 in palm leaf hats for Eddie 
+ Artie.  + a pretty poor investment 
it is.  A letter came to  you from Myron last night.  His hand is 
gaining.  His address is the same
Fort Griffin. If you wish, I will
forward it to you -

   What do you think of Florida

now, + of the South generally?
I think perhaps Chandler will 
go to Minnesota with you, he
talked as though he would this
morning.  I will ask him about 
it before I send this to you -
I do not know when to go to
Marlboro - I guess I shall write 
Mary to-day - We have not had 
a drop of rain yet!  It is very dry-
I confused the new silver with

old yesterday + I found that 
they were not exactly alike-
but so little difference that it 
will hardly be noticed - I have
not found any body yet to do
my washing yet - + I expect - I 
shall have to do it myself, but
I do not feel able to - I hardly
think Chandler will go west at 
present - Chandler + Rhoda
said this noon that they 
wanted we should stay + go 
to the Picnic at Walden's POnd
the 18th of Aug  Had we better 
or not?  I guess we will stay 
till after haying - The children
all seemed glad enough to unclear
unclear.  They all send lots of
love to you + they will write next 
week I presume.  I miss you very 
much - I hope you will get a good 
price for the corn - Write me often-
From your Affectionate Wife A. J. Kendall

you know they always do if
I am on my feet too long.

   Have you got a corn sheller 

yet?  How much do you expect
to get for your corn?
There has been one battle &
the French were victorious.  Will
that effect the price of corn any?
Chandler say every day that
he is going West - but do not 
know as he means it - at all-
I guess your impression about
Artie was somewhat connected 
with your cousin Louisa's story wasn't 
it.  He was well at the time
you was writing + has been since
expecting one night- two, or three nights - ago he had an
attack of Cholera Morbus, + was
quite sick from 2 o'clock in the 
morning till daylight.  He is pretty 
well now for him - Chandler has
just been up here in my chamber &
says he wants you should be sure & tell
him when you intend starting to Minnesota - I will send you
a slip I cut from a paper, As you may tell me what you think of it

Hudson Aug 7th 1870

My dear good husband,

                    I wonder

if you are in the shade
of your corn crib today, writing 
to me.  you was a week
ago to-day + I enjoyed the letters
very much indeed, + so did
the children, we did not
get them till after the children 
were in bed, + I had got 
my night-dress on, but the 
children heard Aunt Rhoda say
that they had got - some
letters, + so they all got up
+ came in to my room + 
I read all the letters to them 
+ we enjoyed them very

much indeed - Artie especially-

He seemed to understand
more of us have been to church to-day - it is funny that I
have not been to Church but once since I left unclear

every word, + kept saying
Pa-Pa - unclear
Artie is well now + seems 
to enjoy himself very much -
he is out doors nearly all 
day, playing in the sand some
of the time + unclear resting
in the shade under the trees.

  Winnie is so good about taking

care of him that I am
going to make him a present -
Georgie tries to take care of 
him but he hasn't the faculty
that Winnie has.  Eddie
has no faculty to care for him
or else he doesn't try.  Winnie
says he don't try, + I guess he is 
about right - Eddie don't behave 
as I would like to have him
at all.  You know if he is where 
any one is noisy + rough, it 
is very easy for him to be the 
same.  I am sorry it is so, -
The children are out under the apple trees enjoying their
selves in the cool shade - Winnie + Georgie said they were going

I have not decided yet
when to go to Marlboro - Chandler 
+ Rhoda seem to want
to have us stay till after their
picnic whic his the 18th.  I do
not know whether I had 
better or not.  Chandler 
finished haying yesterday - 
He says he is going to write
Sam R to come down while
I am here & help him some
If he does I shall not visit
at Maria's  - Last evening
we sat out on the piazza &
had a real old fashioned sing
Rhoda complimented me by
saying she always thought I was a real
good singer - I can not sing
much now any way -
I did a large ironing yesterday +
made bread for Rhoda

 I felt pretty tired last night,

+ the piles trouble me to-day some
to write - but I hardly think they will get their letters ready
unclear we went up on to Round Hill after supper, babies we all -
you know they always do, if I am o

Hudson Aug 14th 1870

My dear good husband;

                     I have just 

written to Mary telling her that
we would be at Mar boro Friday.
I am going to write a short
letter to you to- night, as it 
will be the only chance I 
shall have until we get settled
again at Mary's.  I suppose
you are in Minneapolis to-day.
+ I guess you are writing 
to me.  I wrote you two or
three days ago - We are all 
comfort-ably well - Artie has a
Diarrhea yet but plays round
+ seems pretty well otherwise.
Winnie has something of a 
Diarrhea, but is pretty well-

I had a miserable chill last 
night - the first I ever had since
I came East.  I should not have
had that.  But we had a shower 
+ it cooled the atmosphere so 
much that I was cold in bed.  & 
got up to shut the windows
+ put more clothing on the 
bed, + when I came to get in
bed I went right into a chill, 
+ shook at a great rate for
15 or 20 minutes, + there I 
went into a sweat every time
I stirred or moved all night - I would
chill again.  Artie would kick
the clothes off every little while
+ I had to get up to put them
on, + I would have a chill every
time - I passed a pretty uncomfortable
night - I wished you
was here oh, so much to take 
care of Artie.  I am not feeling
as well quite as usual to-day.

but presume I shall be all
right to morrow - my "periodical"
arrived this morning + i 
suppose that is the cause of my 
bad feelings.  Mr Bassett +
family were over here to-day
he brought over two little boys -
Warren Taft of unclear + George
Tyler of unclear to stay awhile..

 The Sunday School Picnic

is on Wednesday, the 17th -
Chandler + Rhoda want we should
go, + if we are pretty well
I guess we shall.  I wish you 
was here, to go if we do - when
may I expect you back, you
have been gone almost three 
weeks.  I miss you very much
indeed.  + yet I am getting along
better than I expected, with the 
children.  I do not expect I can
control them as well now those
boys are here.  George Tyler is

13 years old, + he is like most 
all other town boys, full of
mischief + ready for anything.
I am sorry he has come 
just now.  The children are
in bed now, but they told
me to send lots of love to you.
You will have to excuse them
from righting to-day for those boys
are here + they cannot get a chance 
very well to write, I will have
them when we get to Mary's -
Chandler says if you do not
find anything to suit you at Minneapolis,
he would like to go down 
+ look in Tennessee with you -
but I do not believe he can find
time to go - I do not believe we
shall like down there it is so
far from railroads, + everything else.
Write me all about your trip north
I guess I should unclear a chill all
this time then - but I must close now
so I must bid you good night - yours

 Affectionately  A.J. Kendall

Marlboro Aug 21st 1870
     Sunday unclear

My dear good Husband;

          Here I am at 

Mary's again & the children
too, all "safe & sound,"(the 
sound means pretty well)-

 We left Chandler's early

Friday morning - Chandler
accompanied us for 
unclear + got us off from
there in the night  car +
then we got along nicely
all the way here Unclear
good was at the Depot &
took us right off, baggage & all -
We found Mary + family
well & glad to see us - The
children seemed delighted to

get back Artie especially.  He 
called for the "Go Lap" the first
thing + unclear off he started
for unclear blocks -  Seemingly as
happy as he could be - The 
other children ran for the play
house, in the wall under the 
maple trees.  It looked & seemed 
very pleasant & homelike
to me, & does still - only 
something is wanted & that 
something, is my dear good 
husband - You was here so
long with us, that I miss your 
presence more here that I did
at Chandler's - WE did not
go to the Picnic at Walden's 
Pond after all - Artie was not
quite right in his bowles & I 
did not dare unclear any sick,
+ I did not dare let the other
children go without me.  Charlie
was not very well either, so Rhoda

thought she had better not 
go, _ so Chandler & Eva went &
we staid at home.  I had a 
pleasant time at Chandler's, but
he was so busy he could not 
spend the time to take us round
any where.  I did not go to 
see Mrs Heywood, the Clairvoyant
Physician.  I thought I 
would wait till we went back
for our trunks, & then you could 
see her too.

  I received your letter from 

Winona, two from Minneapolis
& the last one I received was 
maild at Chicago - you were 
on your way back to Goodland.
I enjoyed the description you
gave of Minnehaha Falls
very much indeed + I shall 
always prize those little flowers
you plucked for me there.  I 
gave one to Marry - You have

received all the letters I have
written you probably unclear this - at 
Goodland - I am anxious to hear
from you again to know if you
have sold your corn & how much you
got from it + if your mind is made 
up in regards to a home.  I feel as
anxious to get settled down again as
you do- Mr. Osgood, in all probability,
has sold this place, + now
he is, or will be, looking around for 
another home.  I have been talking
with him + Mary about going to different
places, if we should go - I think Mr.
Osgood would like to settle down somewhere
near us, either South or West, if 
he thought he could better himself
by it - I think if we conclude to settle
down at Goodland, Mr Osgood would buy
a price of land then + live there unclear
if Mary would be willing to, But she
I know does not like the West -
Mary calls me & says come down, so I'll go-

Marlboro Aug 23rd 1870

My dear good husband

           I wrote Monday that 

Danford (Emily's husband) was very
sick with typhoid dysentery, but
as we had heard nothing since
Friday, we were in hopes he was 
better, - But the sad news came
last evening that he died last 
Friday P. M. about 2 o'clock, + that 
the funeral took place at the house 
Sunday P. M.  We are sorry that
some of us could not have been at 
the funeral - but the letter came 
to late - Emily will feel that her cup
is running over - I feel so sorry 
for her.  it has seemed so melancholy
here to-day.  I have hardly
known what to do with myself
one of your letters said you wonder I should get a marino dress - but
it's come to late - I can get one in Boston, Eddie will have to have an every day
suit of clothes soon.  I got
him in pain of shoes at
Hudson.  The children are 
getting brush together for a 
Bon Fire, to - night - We are
all well as usual.  I hope 
you are well - Wednesday
morn - the children had 
unclear Bon Fire last night-
they enjoyed very much.
Mr Osgood said this
morning that he read 
in a paper that the corn
unclear in New England was 
going to be unclear

I have thought of you a treat deal, + have wished so many times that you was here. I hope you are very well, + will keep well, + will come to me as soon as your can get through your business at the farm. I am sorry corn is no higher. I hope it will come up again before you sell it. I shall write to Chandler tomorrow, + tell him what Mr Osgood has written you + perhaps he may conclude, as we all may, that Goodland is as good a place considering all things, as can be found any where. I got three letters from you Monday, + I thank you a thousand time for them. I hope Andrew Weaver will go where we make up our minds to  - more the merrier you know. The children went out blackberrying yesterday + I should think they got 16 or 18 quarts today they went blueberrying + got about 10 quarts, besides all the berries we can eat we have the very best apples you have ever seen to eat
Mercy + Mr Osgood wish to be kindly remembered to you

Marlboro Sept 4th, 1870
My dear good husband.
I have just finishes a letter to Chandler urging min to go south with you on an exploring expedition. I hope he will conclude to do so.
Mr Osgood + I received your letters written the 28th Aug. day before yesterday,Mr Osgood received another from you yesterday relative to settling in the West - You wrote rather "blue" in regard to the weather in your first letters, but this one yesterday looked a shade or so lighter. Perhaps after all, things will so shape themselves in spite of allwe do to the contrary, that we shall all settle down at Goodland yet. If it is so to be, it will be, I think, any ways
I hope you are better than you last were when you last wrote, How is that miserable () and have you sold any more,+ how is your other grain turning out well I hope, Eddie Winnie + Geprgie are very well indeed. Artie has a Diarhea attach every few days but I have so far kept in check. Ii am not feeling quite well this morning. I over-loaded my stomach yesterday, I suppose The children send lots of love+ ask of () when you are coming,--------

If we could only live in Goodland + be comfortable well, It would be rather a pleasant way to live, to all build in Goodland, good comfortable houses + have sufficient land to raise fruit + vegatables + go into the stock business but in case you do this way I think you had better keep all your lands + buy other land for ?The Asgood + Chandler You know our boys are growing + in a few years they will be able to manage this whole easily + they will want it all - I think this better way is altogether if we settle down at Goddland (strikethrough) west - + go into the stock business to build good comfortable houses in Goodland - put this improvement we make there instead of on the farm for if we should ever sell this farm it will sell for no more with extra improvements on it then it will as it is

& the property in Goodland, would sell for about as much as we could sell the whole farm with the same improvments that we would make in Goodland. This is only my opinion you know, & you can take it for what it is worth—we may go South yet, "The Lord only knows," I'm sure I don't," but I want to go somewhere if we are going to, before it is cold enough to freeze us stiff. I do not believe we had better go South unless we are positively sure, that our healths will be better there. It is very hard getting there, & we should have to sacrifice many things in making the change, many more than we would to settle at Goodland. The only thing that would induce me to go South would be a change for the better, as regards health.

Mother to Father 1870
Mrs Osgood has gone today to attend a funeral about 14 miles from here & it is on his way to the place where he is going to preach tomorrow. he went with his own team + will not be back till Monday night. He + May went with a gentleman + his wife from Westmoreland, yesterday, on to Monadnock Mt so he has had no time to write you since he received your last letters but he told me to say to you from him that he thought you + Chandler had better go South _ satisfy yourselves in regard to climate + stock raising etc + then come on here + talk the matter over + then come to a conclusion in regard to settling. He has sold here + there are nice places there he can buy near here. And if after seeing + talking with you, he is satisfied he can do better elsewhere he will go - He will not make any propositions for buying here unclear after he has seen or heart from you - I have not time to write any more now - with love + good wishes unclear your loving wife Abby Kendall

Marlboro Sept 10th 1870
My dear good husband
your good letter of Sept 4th cam to me yesterday. I thank you a thousand times for the love & good wishes it contained for me & our children. I also thank you for sending another 10 dollars - I ?presume I shall not want to use it till you come, but I like you know to have money in my own purse, that I can use if necessary. -  So you are really homesick down on Prairie Farm! I must confess that I am somewhat surprised at this acknowledgement, but I must confess, also, that I am some what pleased about it because

you can now appreciate my feelings when I went down on to our old Prairie farm & you never could before. You always felt as though I ought not to have felt so & I always told you I couldn't help it to save my life - Although I know & felt all this time that it was such a relief to you. I think if I had not been in a "family way" I should have felt very differently. You know our living was entirely different & everything else was all so different that It took a pretty strong hold upon me, although I tried my best to make the best of it & was not half as ?sicked over it as I might have been. (Perhaps you never knew this) I have had quite a laugh over "that good square meal" that you eat - I am 
in margin
Mary & Mr Osgood wish to be remembered with much love

glad enough you have had one good meal of victuals. I hope it will do you lots of good. I do wish you could have been here the last three weeks - you could have had all the fruit you wanted. I have eat so much, I am getting tired of it. For the last week we have had all the ?plums we could eat, beside tomatos [sic} & apples & blackberries. I never was at a place where I could have all the fruit I wanted before. I received a paper from you day before yesterday an Ashville paper. I have looked it over, but do not like it much or the spirit that exists there between the rebels & the northern people & I should feel afraid to live there. This same old feeling with the South towards the North will exist for long ?years to 
in margin
The boys send their good Papa lots of love & they say they will write you to-morrow. I will try & have them. I asked Artie if he wanted to send Papa is love & he said "Ee"

come I think & for this reason I should dread going there even with a number of friends. The climate I think would be just the thing for us in Winter but in Summer I like New England as well as any place I have been. If we could get 15 percent for our money, we could afford to spend the Winters South & Summers North, couldn't we - but - then there would be the trouble of going back & forth & the expense beside. If we could live in New England. I think Pittsfield would be a beautiful place. I have made no inquiries about it for I couldn't see any body to inquire of & I know of no one to write to. When you come ?over you must unclear & inquire about it. Suppose you write to Dr Gatchel in regard to it. I suppose if you do not go South exploring you will be with me to weeks from today. I must say I shall be delighted to see you. I have no ?sample of Merino that I can send today. Perhaps is well be best to wait till you come before getting it. The boys have got to have new every day shirts as soon as you come. Those they had are all worn out & ?patched The children are well. My old "periodicals" came today. it is time this letter was in the Office. I sent for some

Marlboro Sept 17th 1870
My dear good husband
Your letter of the 11th reached here yesterday. I was glad to get it, but sorry to hear that you continue to raise bloody matter. I think it is caused by being in & inhaling the dust so much. When you get away from it I think you will be better. I think if you can get that land for $10 per acre, it will be the best think you can do to buy it. If we can get it for that I would like to keep the whole of it ourselves - but - I think Mr Osgood would like to take a part of ti, & he can pay for it for the man who bought this place told Mr Osgood that he could let him

have this morning any time. I have not time to write much this morning. I wrote you yesterday telling you about some little trouble existing between Mr Osgood & Kendalls, but there has been a reconciliation & peace prevails again. Mary was not well this morning & I have been quite busy. I got breakfast & have made 8 loaves of bread & some buns. Mr Osgood has gone to Leomaster today - he preaches there tomorrow. He is unclear for some books - he told me what for but i do not now remember & he is gone from home considerably. What do you think of going farther West? Mr Osgood says he had rather go to Goodland. Will you come on East befor eyou go South, if you go? I wish I could send along some of the nice apples & plums that I am eating. I have not heard from Emily yet. The boys send lots of love to you. With love & good wishes & ?passion as ever yours A.J. Kendall

Marlboro
Sept 23, 1870
My dear good noble husband,
I received your love letter yesterday.
I can’t begin to tell you how much I enjoyed it.
I only regret I have not time tell you how
much love is stored away down in the depths 
of my heart for you my good and noble husband.
I thought yesterday when I read your words of love to me
that I would write a long letter of love to you in return
for it but I have not time now if I send this letter 
today. Mary has been sick abed about a week 
and I have the cooking to do and General
superintendance of everything.
I hope I shall not overdo and get sick myself
Mary seems better and is sitting

Up this morning for the first time
Artie is better
The other boys are very well the climate seems to agree with them
I am glad you are going to have some new pants.
If you can get some clothes made at Kankakee
for the boys I think you had better do it, that is, if
you can get them made in time to bring along with you.
They will need them very much.
If you get any get grey or mixed cloth like 
those that Eddie had last winter.
I will send a sample
If it is not just like it
It won’t matter much
have them lined
I do not suppose Mary will be well enough
So that I can do much about getting me fixed up
Emily and Reed were up here last Sunday
Mr Osgood received a letter from you also yesterday . I will remain 
here till you come Eddie is ready so good bye
tillI see you my dearly loved husband.
Yours as ever, Abby J Kendall

Kankakee May 24, 1871
My dear husband
It is half past 6 o’clock so I only have time
to write a word or two tonight.
This has been a lonely day to me
I have had a headache and it has been so warm
I have not had much strength and I feel tired tonight.
Artie is well as when you left he coughed some
last night but not more than he has done.
I gave him aconite and a drink of water and 
it relieved him in a short time.
This does not seem much like the anniversary 
of my birth and wedding day.
I hope you got down there well and will be home soon
as possible. It seems lonely enough when you are away.
The children send lots of love. Artie sends a kiss. I send some of both.
Your loving wife AJ Kendall

Kankakee May 28, 1871
My dear husband,
It is Sunday and a very lonely day to me
when you are away. I attended church
this A.M. Mr. Bucher preached the best sermon I have
ever heard from him that is the most
truthful one. I think that without doubt
that God’s influence is working in the minds 
of some men and women and more in a direct way
than it has for centuries.
I think it is at work in you and in Mr Bucher 
and in Mrs Andrews across the st. judging
by what she says. I felt at the close of the sermon today
as though I wanted to get right up on my feet and shout amen.
The Methodists do. I received your letter last evening.
I had begun to worry about you. The boys have written you and will send love I suppose
Artie said he was going to write two

considerable. For I have received letters from
you before the day after your arrival at the farm and
I understood you would write me the same this time.
I suppose you are at Lafayette today.
Artie is better of his cold but his bowels have been
troubling him just as they did awhile ago and he has been very cross 
and I have not made much headway in my sewing. I have got to have someone to do my work
so I can sew or hire my sewing done. I hope you will be at
home Thursday if not before. I am glad your head is better. I think
if you would work less and exercise more your head would be 
relieved of that roaring entirely. Dr Van Riifarr sent
his little boys up here before I was up this morning with a note saying his wife was being 
confined and he would like to have us keep ? till the
trouble was over but I went to church and ? went home before
I got back. It is very warm and has been since you went away
but I must close so good bye from your affectionate wife,
Abby J. Kendall

Nov 7. 
Abby I went out of town early Monday morning
on business and neglected putting your letter into
the mail hence its delay.
I returned last night and I am pretty well but
Feel the need of rest, let me hear

From you soon. I shall be very busy for the next two weeks
but the excitement is just what I need.
Railroading these times is the most exciting business
I believe in the world.

La Porte 
Jan 16, 1855
My dear friend Abby
I have just written a letter to Mary although 
it is my busy time
I will say a few words to you before I retire let me
thank you for your good letter. It was kind of you and Mary to write me so good a letter
A letter so full of sympathy. It cast a ray of sunshine into my heart and
I hope such rays will come frequently to me from you and Mary.
I will talk to you tomorrow but before I bid you goodnight let
me tell you how I live when I am here in town.
I have a good office with two good rooms and one of these rooms
I have neatly furnished and use as my sleeping room and home.
I eat at the hotel but this is my home.
I am as comfortably situated as I well can be in the absence of my wife.
I am grateful for the blessings I enjoy. I am so well now but cannot
but sometimes wish my good Josephine was with me for our home was a happy one.
The true wife is indeed the life and light of home. But I will bid you good night
and talk with you tomorrow.
Jan 18
I did not finish this letter yesterday as I expected when I commenced it
as I was unexpectedly called out of town yesterday 
had a very hard day’s work. I do not know when I have been as tired as I was
last night and I feel dull today so I am fearful that I shall not write you as good
A letter as you did me but judging from my own feelings I am sure you will
prefer even a short letter to none. When I came home last night I found a good letter in my box at the PO 
awaiting me from sister Lydia.

She is very well and seems quite happy she says she finds excellent society 
in Quincey. She says they have a reading circle that is very interesting. I 
do enjoy very much to sit down with a congenial friend and read and talk about what I’ve read.
Josephine and myself used to spend our evenings in that way when we were well and 
I assure you I miss it very much
She used to save anything she found that she liked to read with me.
You know not how much it enhances the happiness of life to
have such a companion, and you cannot know until you have such a companion.
How few  such companions there are in the world.
I am inclined to believe there are more women than men that desire intellectual and 
spiritual companionship. Man is to apt to become absorbed in his business,
and to take no notice of anything that does not affect  that business. I believe that a majority 
of women have yearnings inexpressible when first marrying for social
companionship but whose hearts are frozen by the icebergs in hearts where they have reason to expect
A living fire. Do you not think so, Abby?
What a terrible chasm it must leave in woman’s heart when she is unable to enjoy that soul
communion with her husband that she so much desires.
Lydia wrote me that the Rev Mr Billings from New England ( Unitarian Minister) calls on her frequently and 
that she enjoys his society much. Do you remember him? I think he preached once in Warwick but I
maybe mistaken however. He preached for sometime in Ware. I am under the impression that
he has some difficulty with his society there.Am I right? Lydia thinks that he is a talented man.
Yes Abby you did guess right. The principles and that have been my stays in days gone by
do have a grea

influence in keeping my heart right even when not
surrounded by the purifying influences of home. 
It does not indeed depend on a woman alone for true piety at home.
The husband has duties as important as those of the wife to keep the
fire of devotion in a constant blaze upon the domestic altar.
She say right when you say she can do much with her
influence in making a happy home but she needs air from others.
This is true her nature is much more sensitive than that of man’s 
and frequently a rude word or look so wound her spirit that
she shrinks from manifesting her spiritual wants.
It does need all the good moral influences of both sexes after all to make a true home.
As in the physical world nothing comes to perfection  without the aid of the sexes.so
I believe in the intellectual and moral world there must be a true marriage in order 
to produce intellectual and moral perfection. I believe that we are as much men and women spiritually 
as we are physically and there is not a true marriage without a union in all respects. The 
male or female mind without its mate is imperfect each needs the other. Where they are brought 
together in true marriage they form a unit.Tell me how these views coincide with yours.
Ask Mary to also write me upon this subject. I want you both to criticize and
tell  me about what you both think I have written in each letter.

have ?enjoyeas is, I sometimes find in my soul burning desires to spend my life in visiting country after country, in travelling through the world, studying the character & history of different nations. Much, very much could be learned so, but there the question will present itself can I not be more useful otherwise. Abby the question will sometimes ?yea after arise. What am I living for; am I merely hoarding wealth slowly it is true at the expense of intellectual & spiritual riches and yes my friend I cannot live a less active life. I try to console myself with the idea that perhaps I am exerting a silent influence that will tell as powerfully upon the world as the influence I could exert through the sacred desk. I know I am exerting an influence, but, I know it is not as high & holy an influence as it ought to be. I have even here made near & dear friends & I am sure that our social interviews are not wholly unproductive of mutual good. But my friend, how are you & Mary spending your time this spring? Pleasantly & profitably I hope. You remind that sister Mary of yours that I have not yet received answer from her for the letter I wrote her about the time I wrote you. Tell her that because I have been naughty in delaying so long to answer your good letter is no reason why she should be naughty too. Tell her I don't believe that she is half as busy as I am still I may possibly be mistaken. You say that Chandler thinks of visiting the west. Tell him I should be very happy to see him here & will give him a true Yankee Welcome. Oh how I should like to visit old New England again, although I have no home there still I feel that I have friends the welcome of whom would gladden my soul.  I have no palce even here that really seems to be like home, but still I think I shall remain in the west until

I go to our common home beyond the valley of unclear How strange & full of mystery is life, is mind. How little we comprehend even ourselves. How little we know of our mortal & moral power or weakness. Oh one time we are full of pure & holy aspirations with an energy that can seemingly overcome all obstacles, against the merest temptation overpowers us & we allow ourselves to be carriers here & there by every changing gust of passion. (Does not the history of your life tell you my friend that you have in your soul illimitable power & yet at times does not that power seem to leave you helpless as an infant? Such is my own history & I am inclined to think it is also of every human soul to a greater or lesser degree.  And why is it thus? Can you tell me my friend? Have we not been ?organized as we have been in mercy? unclear not our Father in giving existence to his children instead that they should all eventually be virtuous & happy & has be not subjected then to trials & temptations & suffering for their intellectual & spiritual well being for there can be no progress either in the intellectual, moral, or physical unclear without corresponding ?exertions Many to be invigorated much have obstacles with which to grapple & overcome & its progress is just in proportion to the energy is just first in its conflict. And abby, are not the sufferings that result from failure quickening influences given by a father's love to ?impel us to renew exertion? So it seems to me. Has your brother Charles returned yet? So you & Mary intend to teach again this summer? By this time I suppose you have both rested & are ready & anxious to resume your former favorite occupation. But while you are both so busy doing good by acting upon the minds of the children unclear your charge may ?find hope than now & then you will send a kind thought to your unclear friend? I remain yours affectionately A Kendall

pageContext.title: Nathan Kendall and Abby J. Reed Kendall letters, 1851-1871
